1. FILLING THE FRAME like a picture postcard. Modest, old spotless  a vision of small town normalcy and virtue. This is the home of MARGARET WHITE and her daughter CARRI to have been scrubbed from roof to porch; it is white. Ev have been washed and bleached. Antiseptic. We hear a woman's voice: MARGARET (o.s.) Carrie! Carrie
The voice is distant but insistent. It is heard, in persp which initially involves:

An all-American sunbathing beauty of eighteen, getting th white bikini running interference between her skin and th The CAMERA SLOWLY PANS OVER the expanse of her body  luxu inch for inch as she dreamily rubs in suntan lotion and l from a transistor radio by her side; she's on a beach bla
As she senses someone standing over her, someone staring grown hedge which separates the Horan back yard from the
What are those?
A terribly appealing little girl, a child of indeterminab white hair which will darken in time. What sets her apart pair of bright button brown eyes; and it's these eyes tha through the hedge.
Hiya, Carrie. Gee you gave me a fright. (turning down the radio) How long have you been there?
(not smiling; pointing with her finger) What are those?
Stella looks where Carrie is pointing; the top of her bik her breasts  white against the golden tan. Stella adjusts modesty of her own but as a reflex at being stared at so
Those are my breasts, honey.
(a beat; then solemnly) I wish I had some.
You will. `Course you'll have to wait a couple of years, but
(a fact) No I won't.
Why, sure you will.
(emphatic) No, I won't. (glancing behind her) Momma says no... Momma says good girls don't.
(at something of a loss) Well, I'm a good girl. And besides, doesn't your mother h
Glances anxiously at the mention of her mother at the Whi She swallows her words so that all Stella and we hear is:
...dirtypillows.
What?
Momma calls them dirtypillows. Says she's got them `cuz she was bad when she made me.
Incredulous. But she senses that Carrie is both perfectly too glances warily over at the White house just beyond th She kneels next to Carrie and tries to laugh it off.
Now, honey, that's just silly. Listen  you must be real hot in that long dress. What do you say we go inside and get us some lemonade, would you like that?
Clearly torn  tempted but in the clutch of some weird ter earth to open and swallow her up. She shakes her head.
C'mon. (offering her hand) It'll be our secret.
Carrie  now really scared  shakes her head and disappears
I can't!
Sure you can. I make it nice and sweet, and

And just at that moment, a figure appears in the second-s Although Stella and we really can't distinctly see throug MARGARET WHITE. The moment this big woman sees her daught out a bloodcurdling scream: MARGARET
Both frozen by this terrible sound

As she sucks in her breath, quivering with fright, lookin quickly to Stella, then back at the White house, then bac seems to smile  or is she about to cry? And then, she's gone  running around the hedge and then u White house as fast her legs can carry her.

Stands there, riveted. Not knowing what's happened, what moment. And then, an incredible CACOPHONY of strange sounds start house  an unearthly babble as Margaret White screams, ran that she's sorry, that she forgot.
Mother! (louder) Mother!
As MRS. HORAN  in an old housedress with the hem falling to answer to her daughter's call.
What in the name of God? What's the matter?
(frantic) I don't know... Carrie was just talking to me, and Mrs. White started screaming and...

The sun glistening brilliantly on it as in the opening sh glass globe over which we counterpoint one mother/daughte babble of another: MARGARET (v.o.) I told you to stay away from there, I told you.... CARRIE (v.o.) I'm sorry, Momma. MARGARET (v.o.) ...to stay away from that girl, that whore... CARRIE (v.o.) Please, Momma! MARGARET (v.o.) ... of Babylon!
Which continues over:
Their eyes riveted on the house  trying, squinting to see
Don't you yell at her like that! Stop that!
That poor sweet child...
Mother, we've got to do something!
What?
Call the police? Mother, call the police!
(not about to interfere; hopeless) The child...

At this point, the hysteric babble reaches its crescendo; in this cacophony as Margaret rants at Carrie to go into as Carrie's frightened little voice proclaims that she fo suddenly the screaming stops and it's quiet  dead quiet.
As it becomes more distinct, visible. There's a low WHIST appears to be a stone the size of a small pebble lands on Another, slightly larger one appears a second or two late and...
squinting, blinking at the pebbles which are coming down

as it's pelted with what are now even larger stones  WHIS like miniature bombs. Stones from a perfectly blue summer day. Stones ranging in size from marbles to handballs. One of them hits a downspout, knocking it onto the lawn. SOUNDS as these pieces of granite tear into the stucco ro The effect is that of a drum being bombarded.
Frozen to the spot: Mrs. Horan with her hands over her ea SOUND of larger and larger stones as they pelt the house screaming:
Stop that! Stop that!
Stella is clutching Mrs. Horan like a child terrified by healthy young woman as her figure in the bikini testifies nightmarish moment.
As still larger stones hail from the sky. And then just as suddenly and inexplicably as they starte
Mrs. Horan with her hands still over her ears, her daught the lawn. Once again, it's quiet.
As one final stone  this one the size of a mere pebble  f the lawn. The image grows lighter and lighter. All the color seems once again into an incredible, silently blazing white. MAIN TITLES.

Now some years later  and no longer glistening so whitely front of the house as the door flies open. Carrie, now si doorway, carrying school books. As she comes out on the p behind her. She is wearing a shapeless, drab dress  much too long, no without style. What remains in this adolescent girl that glimpsed in the prologue are those remarkable eyes. As she comes down the porch stairs, we hear:
Carrie!
Carrie stops, turns to reply into the house.
Yes, Momma.
You come straight home from school.
A moment of hesitation on Carrie's part, a very slight hi
(sweetly) I always do, Momma.
Then she turns, walks to the street, gathering pace, quic

As Carrie walks down the path from the porch and turns at which she passes by where the Horans used to live. Only t one does. It's a vacant lot with a FOR SALE sign out fron the looks of them, the house vanished a long time ago.

Carrie is walking to school, the sun shining brightly abo house, the livelier she seems. We sense that underneath t an altogether different creature than her appearance woul about this possibility, there is MUSIC.
About five, BOBBY bikes on the other side of one of the s a twenty-inch Schwinn with training wheels.
Hey, fart-face! Hey, old praying Carrie! Praying, Carrie, Carrie, praying Carrie!
Carrie favors him with a sweet tolerant smile and goes on background: Bobby, frustrated, stops astride is bike and screams afte Bobby's face
Or as he is known in school, THE BEAK. He is pathetically beak-nosed, almost a caricature of an adolescent reject.
What are you going to leave for us, You people in your big cars Spewing pollution into the air?
We PAN the faces of adolescents, listening with various d reluctance, to:

You people with heavy feet Trampling down the wilderness? You people who peer into the back seats of our cars Hours after you come out of the back doors of your motels Soon all we will have is each other, and that could be en
Or, as he is known to his pupils, BIG BELLY FROMM, at his reading from an assignment paper.
...If you will let us have room enough And air enough And peace enough To love each other As you never could
He sets down the paper, and looks at the class.
We will see, among others, Carrie. We also see TOMMY ROSS  a mid-seventies version of the bo clean-cut, intelligent, athletic.
He is nodding his head slowly, affecting a kind of puzzle
I must say  I must confess  this poem displays an extraor talent... (the knife) ...a talent extraordinary for you, Tommy Ross.
All eyes are on Tommy, who doesn't seem very abashed. In over his head, to the delight of his classmates. But you he is a kid aware of his own popularity and comfortable w
Tommy, this is slightly different from running for a touchdown... Any criticisms?
The usual hesitation. Then Carrie's hand shoots up.
He appears surprised to see Carrie, ordinarily shy, volun
Carrie White?
Her volunteering has surprised her as well. But she's stu on her. And she has to say something. So she does.
It's... beautiful.
He leaves his desk, moving into the class area, seeming t FROMM

`Beautiful.' `Bee-t-ti-ful!' `Oh beautiful for spacious skies, for amber waves of grain.' Is that the beautiful y The class is snickering. Carrie throws a despairing glanc her, and away, embarrassed. Carrie looks down at her desk FROMM
That isn't exactly a criticism, Miss White. (looking around)
Anyone else? (no one else)
Well, at least we've finally gotten Carrie White to say something!

Tommy looks toward Carrie, with something suggesting comp Then he looks toward Fromm, and he is muttering something TOMMY (muttering) You suck. FROMM Tommy? You said something? TOMMY Yes, sir. (moment; "popular" grin) I said... `shucks.'
But everyone in the class knows.

Two teams of girls, among them NORMA WATSON, HELEN SHYRES RHONDA WILSON (sisters although not identical twins), CHR SNELL. Supervising the game is MISS COLLINS wearing a war whistle awaiting the next point. Among the girls is CARRI to come her way. Twenty  Twenty. The ball is successfully served and remains in play for s it back and forth over the net. And then, just when the t over the net toward Carrie. It's evident that the outcome success. She shacks it hard. And on a line Another chorus of groans, with remarks like "Wouldn't you reinforcing them. Chris storms back toward Carrie. CHRIS (low, harsh)
You eat shit! Miss Collins blows her WHISTLE.

Steam partially obscures the girls as they whoop and holl showers. They banter little barbed pleasantries, bits of talk of college  all of which we hear from separate stall One by one the showers are turned off, the girls stepping toweling, spraying deodorant, bras hooked, underpants ste So do words, running into one another, tumbling, drifting `...Tommy says he hated it on me... My sister's husband p sister... too cheap to spend a penny... we'll go after sc meet you... Friday night...' We PICK UP Miss Collins as she steps among the girls, spi shower. She claps her hands together once, smartly. COLLINS
What are you waiting for, Carrie? (as Carrie looks at her)
Bell in five minutes. CARRIE

Oh uh? As Collins departs, and the other girls start to move tow in her shower stall. She is soaping herself. In a virtual moving her hands over her breasts in small, regular, virt out of frame, below her stomach. Slowly, it emerges back just as she and we see this, so do the girls. CHRIS
Peer-iod! Peer-iod! Carrie stares at her dumbly. The other girls are quick to take up the chant. Chris lea GIRLS
Peer-iod! Peer-iod! Peer-iod! Peer-iod! One voice chimes in: NORMA
Plug it up! Others take up this new chant. For a while, like counterp new chant emerges solely: GIRLS
Plug it up! Plug it up! Plug it up! Plug it up! Dime-sized drops are striking the tile floor at Carrie's SUE
For God's sakes, Carrie, you got your period. (as Carrie turns toward her)
Clean yourself up! Carrie seems bewildered. SUE (furiously)
You're bleeding! You dumb pudding, you're bleeding! Carrie looks down and wails, the sound is very loud. A tampon strikes Carrie's chest, plops to her feet. Carri NORMA

She thinks they're for lipstick. Behind her, another girl pretends to throw up. Shrieks of laughter. Another tampon strikes Carrie. Anoth with tampons and sanitary napkins, some from purses, some the wall. As they bombard Carrie: GIRLS

Plug it up, plug it up, plug it up, plug it up.... We isolate Sue Snell at the moment she joins in the chant caught up in what can only be described as a fury. Carrie howls and begins to back away, howling louder and The door is flung open by Collins. COLLINS
What is this? And she takes it in. She jerks the whistle to her mouth, louder than a shriek (which it resembles) or a howl (whic And there is sudden silence. COLLINS (to girls)
Get out! Get out! The girls retreat, Sue last. SUE
It must be her first... COLLINS
Out! As the girls slip out, Collins turns to Carrie, who has b slaps her face, not too hard at first, then with a flash CARRIE
M... M... Miss Collins... COLLINS
Stand up. Take care of yourself. CARRIE
I'm bleeding. One blind searching hand comes up, clutches Collins' whit handprint. COLLINS
Damn you! She hurls Carrie part way across the room toward the brok COLLINS

Get over there! And take one! CARRIE I don't know... COLLINS Never mind the coin slot... It's broken. CARRIE It hurts... my stomach... COLLINS (grabbing her) Do it! Now. CARRIE I can't. I don't know how!
There's a bright flash as a light BULB POIPS, fizzling ou COLLINS What...?
And she looks at Carrie. Her anger seems to seep away. He COLLINS Carrie, don't you know...? (shakes her head, realizing and wondering) You don't. (reaches for Carrie) I'll show you.
HENRY MORTON, the principal, a decent but somewhat ploddi tapping out his pipe as he talks to Collins. MORTON Isn't she a bit old for her...
Well, he can't quite say it. COLLINS
Her first period? MORTON
Ah, yes. COLLINS
Morty, until a half hour ago, I don't think she knew ther was such a thing. He hesitates a moment  noticing Carrie's bloody handprint MORTON
It's hard to believe in this day and age a girl in high school wouldn't know... something... the facts. COLLINS
Well, knowing that mother of hers... MORTON (cutting her off)
Miss Collins, if you'd been with us longer, you'd understand we cannot interfere with people's beliefs. As for the girls  COLLINS
Carrie's always been their scapegoat. So they... MORTON
You'll have to do something. COLLINS
I will. But I understood how those girls felt. The whole thing just made me want to take the girl and shake her.
Ummm. COLLINS
It's just her period, for God's sake. MORTON (cutting in; uncomfortable)
We'll send her home. (to intercom)
Miss Finch, send in Cassie Wright. COLLINS
It's Carrie White. MORTON (fiddling with paper clips on his desk)
Oh. The door is opened. Carrie stands in the doorway. MORTON
Come in, Cassie. Collins starts to correct him, but: MORTON
Close the door. No, wait. (up)
Miss Finch, bring in a dismissal slip. (to Carrie)
I think you might take the rest of the day and go home and, uh, well... take care of yourself, Cassie. CARRIE (hardly a murmur)
Carrie. MORTON
We're all sorry about this incident. MISS FINCH, elderly, spinsterish, goggles in with the yel Morton who initials it. MORTON (to Finch, as she goes)
Thank you. (to Carrie)
Would you like to go to the infirmary?... Carrie is shaking her head. MORTON
...lie down for a while... COLLINS
I think Carrie can go home. MORTON Would you like a ride?
Again, Carrie is shaking her head. MORTON We could call you a cab. COLLINS I'm sure she can walk home. And Carrie, you're excused from gym for a week. Take study hall instead.
Morton picks up the dismissal slip, hands it to Carrie. MORTON We are sorry about this, Cassie. CARRIE (sudden fury) That's not my name!

Two things happen simultaneously; Morton recoils slightly and then tumbles from the desk. Then Carrie goes out. Morton comes around the desk, stoops to pick up the ashtr moment, then looks at Collins. COLLINS (slowly) That reminds me. A light blew out while I was trying to calm her down. MORTON I'll send a janitor to fix it.
Okay, that's reality. He puts the ashtray back on the des "peculiar" thought he may have had.

text: Sue's mother. Out of a margarine commercial  a packaged, mother, good wife. She is preparing dinner; in her line o glitters.
Eleanor frowns momentarily, leaves the kitchen.
Through the middleclass, rather tasteful home, to the fro Eleanor opens the door.
Standing in the doorway. She is a large lady dressed in b sack, which we will discover is bulging with religious tr
Margaret White is not a welcome visitor, but Eleanor Snel ELEANOR
Oh, Mrs. White. MARGARET
How have you been, Mrs. Snell? ELEANOR
Fine. MARGARET
And the doctor? ELEANOR
Fine. MARGARET
And your daughter? ELEANOR
Sue is... fine. An impasse. Finally Eleanor feels constrained to open the face, and: ELEANOR
Won't you come in, Mrs. White? MARGARET
Thank you. She steps inside and Eleanor closes the door behind her, ELEANOR
I think Carrie is in some of Sue's classes. MARGARET
Yes. ELEANOR
Perhaps some time Carrie might visit... MARGARET
I'm here on the Lord's work. ELEANOR
Yes, of course. Margaret is fishing tracts out of her bag. MARGARET
These will interest the doctor and you. Eleanor looks at the tracts with pretended interest ELEANOR
I'm sure they will. MARGARET
And your daughter. ELEANOR (a smile)
Well, I don't think Sue would be  MARGARET (cutting in)
Children are godless these days, Mrs. Snell. Margaret's voice is almost toneless  now and throughout. ELEANOR
My Sue is a good girl. MARGARET
These are Godless times. ELEANOR
I'll drink to that! Humor  and she regrets it immediately. ELEANOR (continuing; quietly)
We'll all read... these. The telephone RINGS. ELEANOR
Excuse me. (retreating)
Please sit down. Margaret doesn't sit, and Eleanor flees into the kitchen.
As Eleanor reaches the phone. ELEANOR

Hello... Betty, can I call you back? Margaret White is he Right... right... Let me get rid of her and I'll call you She hangs up, opens a drawer, takes out some hidden house and drags herself back into the living room.
Margaret is still where we left her. ELEANOR
We'd like to contribute ten... (a look at Margaret)
...twenty dollars. MARGARET
Thank you. I'll give you a receipt. Eleanor shifts from foot to foot while Margaret writes ou ELEANOR
Thank you, Mrs. White. MARGARET

I'll pray you find Jesus before it's too late. What can one say? Eleanor stands there, completely exaspe like a steel, middle-class glove. She accompanies Margare Eleanor is about to close the door, stops, seeing:

text: Sue is coming toward the door. She passes Margaret with a hurries to the front door where her mother is waiting. SUE
That's Carrie White's mother... As Eleanor nods and closes the door. SUE (apprehensively)
What did she want? ELEANOR (indicating tracts)
She gave us these  (conspiratorial sigh)
...and I gave her a donation. Sue's face betrays relief, but Eleanor notices nothing. ELEANOR (brightly)
Well, how was school today? SUE Today? Like always.
HOLD ON Sue, staring at the tracts on the table (or perha leaves). A long beat, then:

Who is sitting in an old Boston rocker by the window in h She is wearing just a slip or perhaps an old terrycloth r on the narrow bed. She is leafing through a teenage magazine on the order of mundane fantasies of models in their pantyhose and underw An escape of sorts. And we reveal Carrie's bedroom in the low attic of the Wh decorated with just the fewest embellishments (i.e. high allow in exchange for her own prices  a crucifix above Ca equally small mirror, a Bible and plastic glow-in-the-dar religious prints and plaster quotations on the wall.
Caught up in the magazine, in the most normal of female f Madison Avenue mind. And then, with that extra sense of p about to be caught doing something it shouldn't, Carrie g see:
As this formidable vision of black strides down the walk. coming home from a funeral; Margaret actually seems to li

Her heart pounding as we glimpse that look of terror we w now encased in the body of an adolescent. As she hears Margaret close the front door and call out h Carrie hastily stashes the magazine under the mattress. Where Margaret is standing by the stove, her back to her CARRIE

Hello, Momma. No response. `And God made Eve from the rib of Adam. And Eve was weak and loosed the raven on the world, and the raven was called Sin  ` She pushes the Bible at Carrie, her finger on the place. MARGARET

Momma! MARGARET

-- the Curse of Blood would never have come on her. She m been tempted by the Antichrist. She may have committed th Lustful Thoughts. The teakettle is WHISTLING louder  a high-pitched scream. CARRIE
